Jul 2018 - May 2019 · 11 mos

Ahmedabad Area, India
Ahmedabad Area, India
Person identification from a surveillance video with image annotations in a live stream. The goal of this project was to point out a person-of-interest based on a set of soft biometric attributes from a surveillance video without prior knowledge. The concept of Gait Soft-Biometric was used and the identification and re-identification of a person based on attributes such as gender, appearance, anthropometrics are used to detect the potential criminal activity at places where security is very essential.

My role was to study the literature and thoroughly in order to develop a highly accurate Machine Learning Model upon extracting the features from the GEI and classify a person based on different traits. After that one can find out a person of interest by query processing in a multi-connected surveillance network that will be made live at the industrial level after completion of the project. To locate the person in the surveillance video, we extended the work of Facebook research of MASK-RCNN to efficiently detect a person in the video while simultaneously generating a high-quality segmentation mask for that person. This project was funded by the Government of India.

Developed and evaluated an Android port of the TENA Middleware. The TENA Middleware enables rapid development of distributed real-time applications. This is part of a larger effort to enable TENA on a variety of mobile/embedded platforms. 

Previously, worked as lead software engineer responsible for developing ground software components for Air Force Special Operations Command’s (AFSOC) initiative to adapt the FINDER Unmanned Aircraft System (UAS) for use as an off board sensing platform. Two key components included sensor guidance and a H.264/MPEG-2 viewer. Sensor guidance is used to dynamically reposition the UAS to follow a ground based moving target based on sensor input. The H.264/MPEG-2 viewer displays video from the sensor along with an overlay containing mission critical information. These two components reduced the crew requirements from two (pilot and sensor operator) to one (sensor operator).

As the lead software engineer on the SYKBUS Lighter-Than-Air (LTA) UAS, developed the SKYBUS GCS. Leveraged existing code from FINDER program and added additional modules for LTA operations. By reusing code we were able to significantly reduce development and testing time.

Once the value of the carrier frequency was selected according to the requirements of the satellite, the bandwidth was calculated according to the C code along with the dimensions of the bandpass circuit, and the width where the screws to be tuned had to be put. Upon creation of the Hardware, the manual tuning of the circuit was done and the results were captured on a Virtual Network Analyser (VNA).

I founded Neo Rostrum Inc. a C-Corporation during the commencement of year 2006. Neo Rostrum is an Italian word where ‘Neo’ stands for New & ‘Rostrum’ stands for Platform. I founded Neo Rostrum Inc with a vision of formulating a newer platform of doing business the right way. During my professional socializing at business communities I realized & learned that the upcoming decade or so (2008 - 2016) was destined to uproot businesses at USA & start-ups survival was next to impossible, so to assist Neo Rostrum Inc survive I successfully planned & pushed Neo Rostrum Inc ‘into dormant state by end of year 2006’ to be resurrected post a decade. Dormant state in a way that Neo Rostrum Inc continued to file its Federal & State Taxations Annually but maintained a very-low-profile of no-profit no-loss status all the way through the decade. As year 2016 commenced, I began the process of Resurrecting Neo Rostrum Inc to bring it back into business. On September 9th 2016 (numerological 999) I succeeded in securing private share investors into Neo Rostrum Inc’s for a good of $500 per share stock price at times when investment market at USA was sloppy and in red. Between September to December of 2016, I successfully convinced United States Postal Service to issue Neo Rostrum Inc a CAPS Account, a Corporate Account & a Bulk Mail Permit, I successfully convinced Bank of America to re-instate Neo Rostrum Inc into its customer pool of Small Businesses, I closely worked with California Franchise Tax Board (CAFTB) in settling arrears of taxes that CAFTB had on books for Neo Rostrum Inc (CAFTB levies $800/- default tax), I paid all the dues in full and CAFTB credited Neo Rostrum Inc account with the excessive payment amount under the particulars of Estimated Taxes, I closed a business deal of providing a Year Long Contractual Information Technology Services to a major renowned Identity Protection Company at USA that serves to almost all of the USA nation.

Driving next generation design & architecture of 2 systems critical to Uber's Build Infrastructure.

- SubmitQueue: Conceived & developed an innovative scheduling system that keeps large monorepos shippable at all times even with 1000s of commits/hr. 

- uCI: Creator of uCI, a generic, scalable task-execution/orchestration system that leverages mesos for powering CI & other stateful workloads at Uber.

Submit Queue:
100s of engineers committing changes concurrently to a repository leads to frequent master breakages. Explored & conceived a new system called "SubmitQueue" that guarantees an "always-green" master in this context. At Uber, Submit Queue handles 100s of commits/hr submitted by ~1000 of engineers every day.

Individual contributions made:
-- Came up the idea of speculatively executing builds that are mostly likely to succeed to scale the system to 100s of commits/hr.
-- Designed and implemented a conflict analyzer to detect if two changes are likely to conflict or not using the build system.
-- Built Machine Learning models that continuously learn & estimate the likelihood of changes to pass builds.
-- Architected the system to handle 100s of repositories, failover-active in all of Uber's regions.
-- Published a research paper at Eurosys'19 introducing SubmitQueue and detailing its core components.

uCI - a reliable task execution/orchestration system for stateful workloads:
Laid the foundation for a world class CI Infrastructure at Uber by replacing Jenkins with a scalable task execution system that leverages mesos for cluster management.

This included writing a complete PostScript clone and guiding the Folio hinted font scaling technology. The combination of the PostScript clone and the font scaling technology enabled Sun to create software to drive inexpensive printers using the CPU power of the desktop, thus instigating suns printing business.

New Delhi Area, India
New Delhi Area, India
The project was to design and implement a modified version of Localized Linear Support Vector Machine (SVM) which is faster and more accurate than standard libraries. The modified SVM first clusters the data using K-NN and K-Means clustering algorithm and then applies a Sequential Minimal Optimization (SMO) based SVM on each cluster, thereby deriving a consensus SVM model that is later used for classification and prediction purpose. Random Fourier Features were used for feature selection and optimization.

My experiments clearly showed that our modified SVM was more efficient (more accurate) and fast when compared to standard available tools like LIBSVM and LLSVM upon running both on standard datasets.

Project Guide - Prof. K. K. Biswas

Created a software that moves petabytes of HFDS data from any private and/or public cloud (like Walmart Data Center) to another one (like Azure's HDInsight or Amazon's EMR) that utilizes MIMO (multiple input/multiple output) pattern to achieve the lowest possible total transfer time - that is only limited by hardware (disc or network bandwidth) and as efficient as possible (low CPU/memory/resources utilization)

Performance Results
To transfer an HDFS snapshot between hosts we are able to transfer data at a throttled 580 Mbytes/sec even across long distance, high latency links (e.g. France to Colorado). Research Scientist (Cryptographer) -- Intel Labs.

At Intel Labs, my research is focused on Post-Quantum Cryptography (e.g., Hash-Based Signatures, Code-Based Cryptography, Lattice-Based Cryptography, Isogeny Based Cryptography and Multivariate-Quadratic Crypto) and lightweight cryptography (lightweight block ciphers, hash functions, authentication, attestation mechanisms, etc).

I am a contributor to international standardization efforts on Cryptography. In particular, I am serving as an expert member of the USA delegation for ISO/IEC JTC1 SC27 (IT Security techniques) Work Group 2 (Cryptography and security mechanisms) and an expert member of the INCITS (the central U.S. forum dedicated to creating technology standards) on Cyber Security (CS1). 

Besides my research track, I am the architect and maintainer of TinyCrypt (https://01.org/tinycrypt), a small-footprint cryptography library targeting constrained devices written in C. I implemented the following cryptographic algorithms in TinyCrypt: AES-128, SHA-256, CBC mode, CCM mode, CMAC mode, CTR mode, EC-DH key exchange, EC-DSA signatures, HMAC-SHA256 and HMAC-PRNG. TinyCrypt is currently used in several open-source projects, including the Zephyr Operation System (https://www.zephyrproject.org/) and the Intel System Studio (https://software.intel.com/en-us/intel-system-studio).

I am also part of the SAFE-Crypto core team, which is responsible for evaluating and approving the usage of cryptography in any mechanism at Intel.

Doctoral Researcher
Doctoral Researcher
Inria

Oct 2010 - Dec 2013 · 3 yrs 3 mos
Oct 2010 - Dec 2013 · 3 yrs 3 mos
Paris Area, France
Paris Area, France
Development of my doctoral thesis:

Subject: Public-key cryptography based on error-correcting codes.

Contextualization: The main hindrance for the practical use of public-key code-based cryptography was its huge public-key sizes (hundreds of kilobytes for reasonable security levels). 

My thesis (main results): Proposition of two different approaches that significantly reduce the public-key size of code-based cryptosystems. One is based on the use of algebraic codes (Quasi-Dyadic Goppa Codes) and another on the use of graph-based codes (Quasi-Cyclic Moderate-Density Parity-Check Codes). In summary, both proposals managed to reduce the public-key size to values comparable to those presented by the RSA scheme, a cryptosystem largely used in practice. Moreover the QC-MDPC proposal strengthens the security-proof of the standard code-based cryptosystems by using codes free of algebraic structure. 

My thesis (complementary results): 
- Extension of the Quasi-Dyadic Goppa proposal for: 1) digital signature scheme; 2) codes defined over finite fields of characteristics greater than two.
- New decoding algorithm for square-free Goppa codes.
- Extension of the Quasi-Cyclic MDPC proposal for cyclic-symmetric codes.
- Preliminary results on the possibility of using random linear codes to instantiate public-key code-based cryptosystems.

- Piloted the use of machine learning classifiers to mine through large volumes of user feedback to surface the top meaningful buckets of issues that users feel the most pained by, thus kick starting the effort that later came to be known as Functional Correctness. 
- Collectively scaled the effort from an experimental project with 1 Facebook App product team to an established program run by 28 Facebook App product teams (with other tooling & product partners).
- Leading this cross-functional effort to now scale across 5 partner orgs (Facebook App, Instagram, Messenger, AdsManager and Workplace), also setting the long term direction and vision for Functional Correctness.
- Actively working as the solutions architect for a framework to systematically address user feedback on the applications, as well as prevent future failures through centralized instrumentation strategies.

I became involved with Blueprint when it started in the spring 2013. Blueprint strives to work with Bay Area nonprofits to provide software engineering solutions, free of charge. I worked on two such projects, in one of which I lead the team. I also served as a technology "chair", maintaining past projects and doing QA work.

The project I lead is called is a crowdfunding portal for Re-volv, a San Francisco based nonprofit organization which provides community establishments with solar power through crowdfunding campaigns. The project entailed leading a team of four student developers and interfacing with RE-volv to inform our technical decisions. The final product includes:

- Dashboard-style tools for various types of donors and volunteers
- Visualizations of solar investment returns and controls for donors to redirect investment returns into new crowdfunding campaigns
- Payment processing via Stripe, including recurring donations

The portal launched in 2015 at re-volv.org, replacing the existing website. I continued to work with the nonprofit to facilitate their transition of the platform first to offshore contractors then to Zibtek, a web application consulting company.

Worked on and started several awesome, impactful projects at Google with stellar teams.

Question Answering from the Web (try queries like 'who did the black swan dance in the movie', 'where did cricket originate' on google). Steven Baker (https://www.linkedin.com/in/steven-baker-5077885) and I started this project called WebAnswers aka Featured Snippets at Google and built a super strong team. This 'open domain q&a' is a very hard problem in NLP / AI domain. Very happy with the huge success of this project in answering a large fraction of users queries. 

Ranklab is a Machine Learning platform focused on ranking systems within Google. Alex Grushetsky (https://www.linkedin.com/in/alexander-grushetsky-2841731) had phenomenal vision in defining and starting this project. We started Ranklab and I grew and managed a superstar team, and focused on working with the customers of the platform. Ranklab is a very successful project internally in Google, with collaborative efforts with Web Search ranking team, YouTube, Image Search and Google Brain team, all resulting in successful launches.

Search Ranking (improvements to ranking algorithms and signals) - various ranking improvements and lead ranking teams to improve ranking signals / subsystems.

Evaluation and Analysis (A/B testing with human raters, live users, traffic trends using logs). This is a critical part of Google Search and the ability to run experiments easily is extremely critical for complex projects that Google launches. I took over the eval engineering team when it was fairly small and grew it to a large team, drove a lot of improvements in performance and software quality working with strong engineers.

Past projects: 
Realtime Search using Twitter firehose (http://googleblog.blogspot.com/2009/12/relevance-meets-real-time-web.html), Tweet replay search (http://googleblog.blogspot.com/2010/04/replay-it-google-search-across-twitter.html), Mustang Search performance improvements (working with Rob Stets).

Insight Data Science prepares fellows for a smooth transition from academia into the data science industry. This is split into two parts, the creation of a data science project over three weeks, and several weeks of studying material that academics may not have otherwise encountered.

My project was a consulting project with HackerRank, called HackerRecruit. The idea behind the project was to maximize ROI of recruiters and heiring teams in software industries, by predicting how likely a candidate is going to clear a interview pipeline. My contributions to the project was to predict likelihood of a candidate clearing the phone screening stage (technical) based on his performance in the online technical screening stage. For this project, I used HackerRank's database stored on Apache Spark Cluster for feature extraction, and used a random forest model for training. Finally, I developed a website on AWS as part of my deliverable, demonstrating prioritized sorting of candidates based on the predicted probabilities of them clearing the phone screening.

Hashtag Recommender System
Hashtag Recommender System
Freelancer- Self employed · Freelance
Freelancer- Self employed · Freelance
Nov 2020 - Dec 2020 · 2 mos
Nov 2020 - Dec 2020 · 2 mos
Hashtag recommender was coded in Python and aims to help users generate a list of optimized hashtags for unlabeled photos. It works by extracting deep features from the input photo and finding six the most similar images from a database of >5,000 Instagram posts. Posts were collected using the search hashtags: #brunch, #food, #cats, #catsofinstagram, #fitness, #mechanicalkeyboard, #nature, #naturephotography, and #tech.

Because recommendations are optimized not only for similarity to image content but also the number of likes associated with each hashtag, the recommendations can be somewhat wacky! But the goal is to maximize engagement using hashtags and not necessarily to describe the image perfectly.

• Designed and deployed Flask web application in production using AWS EC2 instance to improve user experience.
• Wrote modular web-scraper to efficiently automate large-scale data collection from Instagram.
• Developed recommender system using image analysis to extract deep features with CNN.
• Used NLP, Bag of Words, and Skip-gram algorithms to optimize recommendations for maximum engagement.

Co-Founder

Spreads Between the Breads Co. · Self-employed
Spreads Between the Breads Co. · Self-employed
Oct 2015 - May 2016 · 8 mos
Oct 2015 - May 2016 · 8 mos
St. Louis
St. Louis
After realizing that the school was selling PB&Js with barely anything between the breads for an expensive price ($3.50), I decided to sell better products for cheaper ($2.50).

I decided to start within the underclassmen residential area (with $150~200K / year TAM) since other residential areas were much smaller and very sparse. From a survey I designed, I figured out that most people want (to be precise, are fine with) 3:2 PB to Jelly ratio on their sandwiches and preferred Wonder Bread (or had no problems with it). I researched prices of multiple grocery stores and transportation cost to determine the most cost efficient procurement strategy (fancy way of saying where's a reasonably close store with cheap prices). After my first delivery, I set up a communication channel through facebook messenger with customers so I could get feedback after each delivery.

I failed when trying to scale the business. I had 3 major issues - 1) Throughput was too low (couldn't make enough sandwiches in a given time), 2) delivery network didn't exist, and 3) Personnel management. I recognized the existence of first 2 problems and designed solutions - 1) Streamlining sandwich production (1 person spreads the PB, 1 person Jelly, and 1 person puts together the sandwich and packages it) & Designing PB and Jelly dispenser, and 2) hiring students as part-time delivery people.

Without scaling the business, each of the 3 members were making slightly above minimum wage compared to number of hours put in. I failed to sufficiently motivate the other 2 and communicate an upside.
